metadata.title: Journal Pre-proof Vertical transmission of COVID-19: SARS-CoV-2 RNA on the fetal side of the placenta in pregnancies with COVID-19 positive mothers and neonates at birth Title page Full title of manuscript Vertical transmission of COVID-19: SARS-CoV-2 RNA on the fetal side of the placenta in pregnancies with COVID-19 positive mothers and neonates at birth Title: Vertical transmission of COVID-19: SARS-CoV-2 RNA on the fetal side of the placenta

abstract.text: 1 in pregnancies with COVID-19 positive mothers and neonates at birth 2 Research letter 3 Condensation : Detection of SARS-CoV-2 with RNAscope technology in placental samples of 4 positive neonates at birth 5 Short title: SARS-COV-2 vertical transmission 6 7 48

2,660 grams, Apgar scores were 9/10 respectively at 1 and 5 minute, umbilical artery pH was 7.28. 49 The mother wore surgical mask in labor and at the delivery, skin to skin contact wasn't permitted, 50 rooming-in and breast-feeding with mask were allowed. The newborn had positive NP swabs 51 immediately at birth, after 24 hours, and after 7 days; he remained asymptomatic, except for mild 52 initial feeding difficulties and was discharged from the hospital at ten days of life just for 53 observation as this was the first positive neonatal case encountered.

Case 2: The second newborn was delivered by cesarean section at 35.1 weeks from a mother with 55 fever, cough and positive COVID-19 NP swab; the cesarean section was performed for non-56 reassuring fetal status. The neonate was female, weighted 2686 grams, Apgar scores were 9/10 57 respectively at 1 and 5 minute, umbilical artery pH was 7.32, and upon birth she was immediately 58 separated from the mother and admitted to the neonatal intensive care unit. Neonatal NP swab was 59 negative at birth and turned positive at day-7 day, with no contact between mother and neonate 60 during that period. No neonatal complication were observed, only some feeding difficulties were 61 reported in the first days of life; she was discharged on day of life 20 mainly due to routine late 62 preterm care.

The placentas of these two women who delivered neonates with SARS-CoV-2 positive NP swabs 64 (cases 1 and 2) showed chronic intervillositis, with presence of macrophages, both in the 65 intervillous and the villous space. The immunohistochemical study demonstrated chronic 66 intervillositis with macrophages CD68 + infiltration. (Figure 1a-b and 2a-b). 67 After the purification of viral RNA from 200 µl of clinical samples, the detection of RdRp, E and N 68 viral genes was obtained by Real time PCR (GeneFinder TM COVID-19 Plus RealAmp Kit 69 (Platform ELITe InGenius ® , ELITech Group, France) according to WHO protocol. 2 We performed 70 an ISH (in situ hybridization) with RNAscope technology, a method that enables the detection 71 through the V-nCov2019-S probe the SARS-CoV-2 spike protein mRNA . We tested not only case 72 1 and 2, i.e. the positive COVID-19 mothers with positive COVID-19 neonates, but also two 73 negative controls: a positive COVID-19 mother with negative COVID-19 neonate (case 3) as well 74 as a negative COVID mother and neonate dyad (case 4). Individual and clustered brown 75 chromogenic dots using a standard bright field microscope were observed in the 76 syncytiocytotrophoblast of both placentas of mothers of positive COVID-19 neonates (Figure 1c

77 and 2c). No evidence of positive dots were seen in the positive COVID-19 mother with negative 78 COVID-19 neonate (Figure 3c; case 3), as well as in case 4. Positive control probes were well 79 expressed in all tissues tested and the negative control probe ensured that there was no background 80 staining related to the assay and that tissue specimens were appropriately prepared. No significant 81 alterations were detected in the other placental histologic examinations of all women COVID 19 82 positive who delivered infants with negative swabs. 83 84 Discussion 85 The possibility of SARS-CoV-2 vertical transmission is still controversial. Literature reporting 86 evidence of vertical transmission is limited. 3 Two reports described presence of elevated SARS-87 CoV-2 IgM antibodies in three newborns, but repeated NP samples in the infants were negative. 4 88 Wang et al 5 reported one case with positive qRT-PCR in both the mother and the neonate. The

89 neonate was delivered by cesarean section, transferred to the neonatology, the baby had no contact 90 with the mother and neonate's NP swab turned out to be positive 36 hours after birth; in this case 91 swabs from placenta were negative, but a possible mother-to-child transmission of SARS-CoV-2 92 cannot be excluded. Penfield et al. reported the presence of SARS-CoV-2 RNA in 3/11 placental 93 samples from COVID 19 positive women. None of the infants tested positive or demonstrated 94 symptoms. 6 95 To our knowledge, ours is the first report of cases of positive PCR for SARS-CoV-2 in mother, 96 neonate and placental tissues. The RNA ISH assay gave us the possibility of direct visualization of 97 the virus, evaluating the molecular target SARS-CoV-2 spike protein mRNA while retaining tissue 98 morphology, a feature that is lost in other methods such as PCR. The RNAscope probe detected 99 positive staining for COVID-19 viral RNA in the infected tissues but not in the uninfected placentas 100 demonstrating the specificity of RNAscope probes. The presence of SARS-CoV-2 RNA in the 101 syncytiothrophoblast signifies presence of the virus on the fetal side. 102 Conclusions 103 This is the first study describing SARS-CoV-2 RNA on the fetal side of the placenta in two cases of 104 mothers infected with COVID-19 and with neonates also positive for the virus at birth. These 105 findings support the possibility of vertical transmission of SARS-CoV-2, the virus responsible for 106 COVID-19 infection, from the mother to the baby in utero. 107 Moreover, the direct visualization of SARS-CoV-2 RNA in the infected placentas raise the 108 possibility of estimating the viral load in cells with morphological context. Further studies are 109 required to confirm our results. References 116 1. Wang F, Flanagan J, Su N, et al. RNAscope: a novel in situ RNA analysis platform for 117 formalin-fixed, paraffin-embedded tissues.

body_text.text: Hospital in Bergamo between March 5, 2020 and April 21, 2020 were included in the study.
Maternal and neonatal charts were retrospectively reviewed. Institutional Review Board approved 17 the study and informed consent were obtained from the patients.
All the placentas were collected at birth, and sampled and analyzed at Papa Giovanni XXIII 20 Hospital.
Paraffin-embedded formalin-fixed placentas sections were incubated with hematoxylin and eosin 22 (DAKO) and anti-CD68 antibody (mouse origin , Clone KP1, DAKO) that stains macrophages.
Case 1: The first neonate was vaginally delivered on March 27, after spontaneous labor of a mother with fever, cough and positive COVID-19 NP at 37.6 weeks of gestation. Neonatal weight was

FIGREF1.text: collected a nasopharyngeal swab (NP)(FLOQSwab, Copan, Italia)  in UTM (Universal 25 Transport Medium, Copan, Italia) respectively from mother and newborn and a sample of placental 26 biopsy that was stored at -80°C in Biobank after treatment with RNAlater-ICE (ThermoFisher proteinase K (QIAGEN, Germany) and 200 µl of Tris -EDTA buffer solution (Sigma-Aldrich, Germany) for an hour.

FIGREF2.text: Single-molecule RNA in situ hybridization31    SARS-CoV-2 (COVID-19) virus has been detected applying the RNAscope ® technology (ACD, 32 Advanced Cell Diagnostics), an RNA in situ hybridization technique described previously. 1 Paired 33 double Z oligonucleotide probes were designed against target RNA using custom software. The34 following probe was used : V-nCoV2019-S, 848568, NC_045512.2, 20 pairs, nt 21631-23303. The 35 RNAscope 2.5 LSX Reagent Kit-Brown IVD Automation (Leica BOND III ) was used according 36 to the manufacturer's instructions. FFPE tissue section samples were prepared according to 37 manufacturer's recommendations. Each sample was quality controlled for RNA integrity with a 38 probe specific to the housekeeping genes UBC (Ubiquitin C) and PPIB (Cyclophilin B). Negative 39 control background staining was evaluated using a probe specific to the bacterial dapB gene. Each 40 punctate dot signal representing a single target RNA molecule could be detected with standard light 5, 2020 and April 21, 2020 twenty-two women affected by COVID-19 infection 44 delivered at Papa Giovanni XXIII Hospital, Bergamo, Italy. 45 Two of the 22 neonates, born from COVID-19 mothers, resulted positive for PCR of NP swab.

FIGREF3.text: Case 1: Covid positive mother and neonate, with SARS-CoV-2 antigen seen in villous syncytiotrophoblasts, i.e. fetal side of the placenta. A. Chorionic villi showing chronic intervillositis with macrophages. Paraffin-embedded formalinfixed placenta sections at standard brightfield microscope 20X ; Tissue sections stained with hematoxylin and eosin(H&E, 20x). B. Macrophages in intervillous spaces highlighted by anti-CD68 immunohistochemistry. C. In-situ hybridisation for SARS-CoV-2 highlighting the presence of SARS-CoV-2 spike antigen in villous syncytiotrophoblasts. Black arrows show brown dots positive signals of COVID-19 inside syncytiotrophoblast of chorionic villi cross section.

FIGREF4.text: Case 2: Covid positive mother and neonate. Covid positive mother and neonate, with SARS-CoV-2 antigen seen in villous syncytiotrophoblasts, i.e. fetal side of the placenta. A. Chorionic villi showing chronic intervillositis with macrophages. Paraffin-embedded formalinfixed placenta sections at standard brightfield microscope 20X; Tissue sections stained with hematoxylin and eosin (H&E, 20x). B. Macrophages in intervillous spaces highlighted by anti-CD68 immunohistochemistry. C. In-situ hybridisation for SARS-CoV-2 highlighting the presence of SARS-CoV-2 spike antigen in villous syncytiotrophoblasts. Black arrows show brown dots positive signals of COVID-19 inside syncytiotrophoblast of chorionic villi cross section.

FIGREF5.text: Case 3: COVID positive mother but COVID negative neonate, i.e. control placenta with virus not visualized. A. Normal chorionic villi. Paraffin-embedded formalin-fixed placenta sections at standard brightfield microscope 20X ; Tissue sections stained with hematoxylin and eosin (H&E, 20x) B. Normal placental tissues incubated with anti-CD68 antibody. C. In-situ hybridisation for SARS-CoV-2 with absence of SARS-CoV-2 spike antigen in villous syncytiotrophoblasts.
